citations.narrative:
On April 29, 2025, a red kangaroo by the name of "Sheila" escaped her primary enclosure, left the property, and was
located traveling alongside interstate 85. The facility implemented their contingency plan and successively captured
Sheila. She was then transported back to the facility where she received a veterinary exam and was determined to be in
good health. Outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the
animals from injury and to contain the animals within. A failure in this could lead to injury or escape from the facility.
Escaped animals have the potential for increased stress, discomfort, developing health issues, or being killed. Correct by
ensuring that all housing facilities are structurally sound and maintained in good repair to protect the animals and prevent
future escapes. Corrections were made prior to the time of the inspection.

The following deficiencies were identified with the facility’s perimeter fence:
- During the incident on April 29, 2025, the perimeter fence did not act as a secondary containment system for the red
kangaroo named "Sheila" who escaped her primary enclosure and was then able to leave the property.
-A new pasture that houses two capybara is not surrounded by the required 6-foot perimeter fence. This fence must be 3
feet in distance away from the primary enclosure.
Outdoor housing facilities must be enclosed by a perimeter fence constructed so that it keeps animals as well as
unauthorized persons out and functions as a secondary containment system for the animals within the facility. Correct by
July 7, 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
On April 29, 2025, a red kangaroo by the name of "Sheila" escaped her primary enclosure, left the property, and was 
located traveling alongside interstate 85. The facility implemented their contingency plan and successively captured 
Sheila. She was then transported back to the facility where she received a veterinary exam and was determined to be in 
good health. Outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the 
animals from injury and to contain the animals within. A failure in this could lead to injury or escape from the facility. 
Escaped animals have the potential for increased stress, discomfort, developing health issues, or being killed. Correct by 
ensuring that all housing facilities are structurally sound and maintained in good repair to protect the animals and prevent 
future escapes. Corrections were made prior to the time of the inspection. 
3.127(d) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
The following deficiencies were identified with the facility’s perimeter fence: 
 
- During the incident on April 29, 2025, the perimeter fence did not act as a secondary containment system for the red 
kangaroo named "Sheila" who escaped her primary enclosure and was then able to leave the property.  
 
-A new pasture that houses two capybara is not surrounded by the required 6-foot perimeter fence. This fence must be 3 
feet in distance away from the primary enclosure.  
 
Outdoor housing facilities must be enclosed by a perimeter fence constructed so that it keeps animals as well as 
unauthorized persons out and functions as a secondary containment system for the animals within the facility. Correct by 
July 7, 2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.

n

species.common: CONGO AFRICAN GREY PARROT / GRAY PARROT
